p:
For RHBN and non-RHBN watersheds, n ranges 0.442–3.295 and 0.285–9.305, with a mean value of 1.279 and 2.218, respectively (see Supplementary Tables S1 and S2). Higher n means higher E for a given P and E
p , and hence a lower runoff ( R). For example, non-RHBN watersheds #4 and #13 have similar P (about 1000 mm) and E
p (about 700 mm), but watershed #4 has high R (about 500 mm) because of low n (1.525) while watershed #13 has low R (about 350 mm) because of high n (2.712). From periods-1 to -2, most southern (northern) watersheds have become wetter (drier), as E
p / P in the south (north) decreases (increases). E/ P tends to increase especially in CR but it also decreases elsewhere ( Supplementary Fig. S5). E/ P~E
p / P relationships for most watersheds in periods-1 and -2 do not follow the same Budyko curve ( Supplementary Fig. S6), which likely implies that streamflow changes were induced by human impacts, especially when they change in an opposite manner.
